bibl.title: Letter from William L. Lazear to Jesse W. Lazear, September 7, 1876

div1.p: William Lazear writes about the Centennial Exhibition. He also provides family news.

div1.head: Letter from William L. Lazear to Jesse W. Lazear, September 7, 1876
div1.opener:
CIRARD HOUSE
N E COR.9 & CHESTNUT STREETS.
C.Mc KIBBLN & SON.
PROPRIETORS.
Philadelphia Sept 7 1876
My Dear Son
div1.p:
Mama and I had some
difficulty in finding a place to sleep
last night -- all the Hotels and
most of the boarding places being
well filled -- We took supper
at a Restaurant and by waiting until
after 10 oclock we got a room
next to the roof in this Hotel --
-- The day has been so disagrea-
ble that I could not look for an-
other place so we will probably
remain here until we leave --
which we now expect to do on
Saturday evening in time to reach
home at 8 oclock

- Although it rained all day we
lost little time in seeing the
Exposition sights -- Went through
part of the main building - and the
Machinery Hall -- and when
we get home we can exchange
observations with you --. We
went into the Art Galery -- but
the ventilation there is so bad --
that we could not remain long in
it -- We hope to spend most of
tomorrow there -- as we both agree
in thinking that is the chief object
of interest here although all is
grand beyond discription --

-- I called up late yesterday
evening on Uncle Bainbridge and
it was well I did so, for he
and his party left this morning for
Uniontown -- Aunt Virginia's sister,
Mrs Clark, and family took the room
they had occupied at a Boarding
House --

If you go out to Windson on
Saturday tell Grand Pa we are
having a very pleasant time and
both of us feel rested by this
visit -- the pleasant excitement
we have does not fatigue us
in the least --

Give much love to dear little
Charley, and Grand Ma -- and be
a good boy
